result.rationale: Rasbora armitagei is a range-resticted, point endemic freshwater fish species recorded only from one location in Weralugahamulla, near Rakwana in the Kalu River drainage in the wet zone of Sri Lanka. It's estimated Extent of Occurence (EOO) is 4.2 km2 and its Area of Occupancy (AOO) is 4 km2. A continuing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat has been observed as a result of deforestation due to the expansion of tea plantations, leading to water pollution by agrochemicals and siltation. Considering all these factors, the species is currently facing an extremely high risk of extinction in the wild. Therefore, it is assessed as Critically Endangered.
result.geographicrange: Rasbora armitagei is an endemic freshwater fish species recorded only from Weralugahamulla, near Rakwana in the Kalu River drainage of the wet zone of Sri Lanka (Silva et al. 2010).
result.population: There is no population data available for this rare species. It can be inferred, however, that this species faces a decline in population numbers owing to habitat degradation caused by threats such as pollution.
result.habitat: Found in shady, slow-flowing clear water streams with gravel and boulder substrata. Prefers areas with marginal vegetation (De Silva et al. 2015).
result.threats: Deforestation due to expanding tea plantations in the area leads to change the stream habitat (water pollution and siltation) as this species is a point endemic, such alterations to its habitat could result in its extinction (De Silva et al. 2015).
result.conservationmeasures: There are no documented conservation efforts in place.
result.usetrade: There is no known information about the use of this species in the aquarium trade.
